text:
I made a test.dbf file with 2000 records and filled the memofield with 3000 words.
In 3 of the records, I inserted a word that fits the pattern.
Search takes 8  hundredths.
I think for a blog database this search is sufficient.

elements.text:
I made a test.dbf file with 2000 records and filled the memofield with 3000 words.
In 3 of the records, I inserted a word that fits the pattern.
Search takes 8  hundredths.
I think for a blog database this search is sufficient.

text:
nSec := seconds()

  aIdxTest := {}
  htest := {=>}  
  nSec := seconds()
  // for I := 1 to 10000
  use ( hb_GetEnv( "PRGPATH" ) + "\data\testsearch.DBF" ) new
  do while .not. eof()
  if hb_WildMatch(  "*otto*", field->text )
  cSearchFound += str( recno() )
  endif

    AADD( aIdxTest, (  ALLTRIM( STR( recno() ) ) + "_section"  )  )
    htest[  ALLTRIM( STR( recno() ) ) +"_section" ] = STRTRAN( field->section, CRLF, '<br>' )  
    AADD( aIdxTest, (  ALLTRIM( STR( recno() ) ) + "_icon"  )  )
    htest[  ALLTRIM( STR( recno() ) ) +"_icon" ] = STRTRAN( field->icon, CRLF, '<br>' )  
    AADD( aIdxTest, (  ALLTRIM( STR( recno() ) ) + "_header"  )  )
    htest[  ALLTRIM( STR( recno() ) ) +"_header" ] = STRTRAN( field->header, CRLF, '<br>' )  
    AADD( aIdxTest, (  ALLTRIM( STR( recno() ) ) + "_text"  )  )
    htest[  ALLTRIM( STR( recno() ) ) +"_text" ] = STRTRAN( field->text, CRLF, '<br>' )  
    
    select testsearch
    skip
  enddo
  select testsearch
  use

' )       AADD( aIdxTest, (  ALLTRIM( STR( recno() ) ) + "_icon"  )  )     htest[  ALLTRIM( STR( recno() ) ) +"_icon" ] = STRTRAN( field->icon, CRLF, '
' )       AADD( aIdxTest, (  ALLTRIM( STR( recno() ) ) + "_header"  )  )     htest[  ALLTRIM( STR( recno() ) ) +"_header" ] = STRTRAN( field->header, CRLF, '
' )       AADD( aIdxTest, (  ALLTRIM( STR( recno() ) ) + "_text"  )  )     htest[  ALLTRIM( STR( recno() ) ) +"_text" ] = STRTRAN( field->text, CRLF, '
' )            select testsearch     skip   enddo   select testsearch   use

text: Filenames, you mean

text: I am too old for this contest. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I am too old for this contest.

text: Unix goes back longer than DOS. But it might very well be that at the time DOS was perfectly in line with most other systems in having case-insensitive filenames.

elements.text: Unix goes back longer than DOS. But it might very well be that at the time DOS was perfectly in line with most other systems in having case-insensitive filenames.

text: It's just that now, every system other than Windows (including experimental ones like Fuschia or Haiku) is case-sensitive.

elements.text: It's just that now, every system other than Windows (including experimental ones like Fuschia or Haiku) is case-sensitive.

text: also, Windows won't let you have a colon in filenames because it conflicts with the PATH syntax or something. Linux will.

elements.text: also, Windows won't let you have a colon in filenames because it conflicts with the PATH syntax or something. Linux will.

text:
This is a productivity killer. Imagine the senseless troubleshooting time.
Other example
We in Austria have a disadvantage compared to the Americans when signing in the server.
In German the  standard admin is called Administrator.
The word is longer and there are so many typing mistakes.

elements.text:
This is a productivity killer. Imagine the senseless troubleshooting time.
Other example
We in Austria have a disadvantage compared to the Americans when signing in the server.
In German the  standard admin is called Administrator.
The word is longer and there are so many typing mistakes.

text: It's only a productivity killer and takes non-trivial troubleshooting if you're used to case-insensitive filenames.

elements.text: It's only a productivity killer and takes non-trivial troubleshooting if you're used to case-insensitive filenames.

The young people in our company do everything with voice-control.

text: Allá por el siglo 14, la J actual del español era dos sonidos, /ʃ/ (la "sh" del inglés), escrita con X, y /ʒ/ (el sonido de "vision" en inglés, o del acento uruguaʒo), escrita J (o G antes de E y I),

elements.text: Allá por el siglo 14, la J actual del español era dos sonidos, /ʃ/ (la "sh" del inglés), escrita con X, y /ʒ/ (el sonido de "vision" en inglés, o del acento uruguaʒo), escrita J (o G antes de E y I),

text: Luego los dos sonidos se pasaron a pronunciar /x/, y mucho después, se pasaron a escribir solo con G y J, con contadas excepciones.
